name: Malagasy Giant Jumping Rat
description: It doesn’t resemble typical hamsters, with large ears, a long tail, and notably strong hind legs. It is gray-brown to reddish above, with a whitish belly and legs. The head and tail are dark.
spread_note: Small area on the west coast of Madagascar
image_alt: Malagasy Giant Jumping Rat, photo: Vladimír Motyčka, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 30–35 cm; tail length 21–25 cm; weight 1–1.5 kg
attractions: It stays on the ground, moving with hops somewhat like a rabbit. It spends much time digging and repairing a system of burrows inhabited by family groups. Burrows can be up to 5 m long with multiple entrances. The female raises the young in the burrow, while the male defends the territory and often protects young that have left the burrow from predators. Little is known about their wild life as they hide underground during the day and are mainly active at dusk.
projects_note: Due to their limited range and unusually slow reproduction for rodents, their numbers have sharply declined over the past century. Today, they are rare and listed as an endangered species on the IUCN Red List.
breeding: We acquired Malagasy giant jumping rats in 2000 and have since bred eight young.
